questions.question: An increase (rightward shift) in the demand for a good will tend to cause
options: an increase in the equilibrium price and quantity.
an increase in the equilibrium price and a decrease in the equilibrium quantity.
a decrease in the equilibrium price and an increase in the equilibrium quantity.
a decrease in the equilibrium price and quantity.
questions.explanation: Increased demand shifts the demand curve rightward, leading to higher equilibrium price and quantity.

questions.question: If the price of a good is equal to the equilibrium price,
options: there is a shortage (i.e. an excess demand) and the price will fall.
the quantity demanded is equal to the quantity supplied and the price remains unchanged.
there is a surplus (i.e. an excess supply) and the price will rise.
there is a shortage (i.e. an excess demand) and the price will rise.
there is a surplus (i.e. an excess supply) and the price will fall.
questions.explanation: At equilibrium, Qd = Qs, no shortage or surplus, so price is stable.

questions.question: If the price of a good is below the equilibrium price,
options: there is a shortage (i.e. an excess demand) and the price will rise.
the quantity demanded is equal to the quantity supplied and the price remains unchanged.
there is a shortage (i.e. an excess demand) and the price will fall.
there is a surplus (i.e. an excess supply) and the price will rise.
there is a surplus (i.e. an excess supply) and the price will fall.
questions.explanation: Below equilibrium, Qd > Qs (shortage). Competition among buyers drives price upward toward equilibrium.

scoreMessages.90: Mastery of equilibrium analysis and market interventions.

scoreMessages.50: Basic understanding; focus on shortage/surplus dynamics and policy effects.
scoreMessages.0: Review: market equilibrium, price floors/ceilings, and elasticity calculations.
